*-- LONG READ --*



There really aren't many cons to either of the systems. It's mainly about 
preference. The Xbox One masters the overall entertainment aspects, 
designed to be an entertainment center in a console for the modern living 
room. The PlayStation 4 specializes in top-notch hardcore gaming with 
assurance for the highest in gaming quality.

While Xbox One and PlayStation 4 have their strong suits, they also succeed 
beautifully in other aspects. Deciding the console war's champion really 
depends on whatever it is that you prefer. But that's just choosing your 
champion for your own personal console war, not the winner overall. 
Degrading someone else's preference in the matter is asinine.

*I went for the Xbox One* for a few reasons: I personally love the Xbox One 
and Valve's Steam Machine's console designs (they go beautifully well with 
my TV stand), I love the Xbox's gimmickry, I've established myself on 
Xbox's social service, I prefer Xbox's controllers and interface, and Halo 
(as expressed in my profile avatar).

*I'm envious of PS4* because of its incredible exclusive titles (no game 
has ever come as close to making me tear as much as The Last Of Us), IM 
chat system, and indie games at launch. Not to say PS4 is "less wow-ing". 
It just means I prefer other things. Not everyone will share my 
preferences. They're not *supposed* to.

There are a lot of benefits to both systems that don't really appeal to me. 
I know Halo 5 is confirmed to look pretty in native 1080p, running at 
60FPS, so I could care less about a few launch multi-plats, and console 
size isn't really a factor for me, seeing as I'm not going to be holding 
the actual console itself as I play. These are just *my* preferences, 
however.

Had the PlayStation 4 and Xbox One switched roles, I'd jump ship to 
PlayStation. I'd miss Halo, but it's not worth purchasing an entire system 
I won't enjoy for the long run.

I know everyone who knows better already know this, but to the fanboys:

Parading the fact that you blindly allege yourself to a company will only 
make asses out of yourselves. No console is "dying out" simply because it 
doesn't do what *you* expected it to, and to think of any corporation as 
big as Microsoft and Sony as "good guys" is childish. Good guys don't 
heavily restrict consoles for extra cash, nor do they hire Bain & Co. 
(famously known for being close associates with Mitt Romney) to layoff 
dozens of workers in an attempt to save $100,000,000. You know what does? 
Corporations. That's how they strived up until now in the first place.

*-- FUN FACT: 720p rumors FALSE --*

Wanna know why the launch titles for Xbox One run upscaled to 1080p and 
such?

For one, Microsoft were inconsistent with their hardware during 
development. They used high-end PCs to showcase gameplay demos, but they 
kept changing up the hardware during development. The devs behind CoD: 
Ghosts had the game developed before they had the hardware to work on. 
Console optimization was not a luxury devlopers for the Xbox One had.

Second, Kinect. Currently, Kinect 2.0 takes up 10%~ of the Xbox One's GPU 
time *at a minimum*. This can actually be fixed via software patch, but 
there's a big factor in Xbox One's launch title issues.

Lastly, Xbox One launch titles were set back in development. Details are 
scarce, but the news has been reported a while ago by IGN, Machinima etc. 
Microsoft's ride to Xbox One hasn't gone, at all, smoothly.

On the bright side, not only will all these problems be resolved in, say, 
the upcoming year, the Xbox One has more in store. For example, the Xbox 
One's Azure cloud computing and its 300,000 Xbox LIVE servers to work on, 
soon to be made available to devs. To sum things up, the Xbox One will 
continue to evolve over time.

There you have it. Halo 5 is confirmed to run in native 1080p at 60FPS. 
Same goes for the Tomb Raider port. It's too late to dub the Xbox and 
PlayStation as 1080p/720p machines at launch. Last console generation 
should've taught us that. Everything's going to be fine.

Go ahead and consider me an Xbox fanboy/apologist. First of all, had I 
actually accepted people calling me "Xbox fanboy", "Microsoft fangirl", 
"PlayStation fanboy", "Sony fanboy", "PC elitist", and "Nintendo apologist" 
as fact, I'd be stuck in fanboy-purgatory. The reality of the matter is 
that what I say is true, and you can verify for yourselves, seeing as 
you're already on a type of computer.

Of course, were you to have trouble finding the proof to support my claims 
for some mysterious reason, I could always pull up my research right here. 
I always do my research before deciding on a purchase anyway. Better to 
confirm for yourself than to take it at face value.﻿

As im watching this... I see very little differences between the two 
graphics wise... why is this?? It's because they run the same GPU an AMD 
Raedon 7000 series... and I'm thinking to myself while also watching the 
IGN video... why are they showing two different scenes? What I mean is.. in 
the scenes they show for the XB1 and PS4 they seem a couple seconds off 
from one another... usually by about a second or too... a good example of 
this is the guy behind the truck at 10:37, he is behind the bed on the 
right, and to the left he is more to the back of the bed... that's at least 
a second difference... why does this matter? A lot of things can happen in 
a second... the players visual perspective of the scene, lighting in the 
game, and particles and scenes in the game can change... same image... like 
the dust cloud in the back... So the XB1 appears in all images to be 
slightly ahead in time than the PS4... so it makes me question  IGN's 
ethics...

Another thing im thinking about ( keep in mind I don't own a PS4 or XB1 ) 
is this 720p vs 1080p... XB1 just doesn't have only 720p they can make 
1080p, but this depends on game length... why? Because the XB1 is running 
two OP's at the same time while game play is going on, this chews up RAM... 
believe what you want when you read articles saying PS4 offers up less RAM 
than XB1 yada yada... but facts are facts... two OP's running at the same 
time... that's gonna chew up your RAM... not to mention the fact you will 
be running TWO OP'S and the GAME, this is why it depends on length of 
game... if the game is short... takes a few hours to complete, as opposed 
to a few days or however many hours... than you are gonna get 720 vs 
1080... PS4 won't get that because it operates on one OP so its always 
1080...

if I were to do a comparison in my home... let's say for shits and gigs... 
i'd be willing to bet based on the tv I have and the distance at which I 
play ( I have a 42" 1080p, and I sit about 7' away..) I'd be willing to bet 
my last dollar that PS4 graphics would look better than XB1... I don't know 
by how much... but if you take a 720 game, and put it on a large 42 1080.. 
it's not gonna look as clean and crisp as a 1080p game on 1080p 42" tv... 
and that is just fact... So while IGN can pretty much say XB1's graphics 
are better... I am highly skeptical based on this paragraph which is fact, 
and the upper two paragraphs which are educated opinions... so I am still 
highly skeptical about which console to buy, I am still leaning towards 
PS4, but that's only because they didn't try and juke their fan base, and 
all their games will be 1080p... so I am slightly leaning to PS4, but I 
definitely am still torn because I do like all the options for 
entertainment on the XB1﻿

With the next generation just around the corner it's time for that all 
important question: Which console are you going to buy first? Yes, we just 
made the assumption that you are hardcore enough to end up with both 
eventually. Here a five good reasons to pick the PS4 over the Xbox One. 

5. Better Design

The look of a console might not seem important to you but it is. Think 
about it: you'll be looking at this box for a number of years even if it's 
tucked away under your television. Now compare the sleek PS2-style look of 
the PS4 with the old fashioned VCR-design of the Xbox One. Yup PS4 wins 
this one hands down.

4. Lower price

Now this one is easy. The PS4 is a hundred euro or dollars cheaper than the 
Xbox One. We know Microsoft is packing in the Kinect but we prefer Sony's 
way of making the Playstation Eye optional and lowering the price tag. The 
softer approach that Sony has taken stands out due to giving the gamer a 
choice.

3. Indie support

Sony have reaffirmed their dedication to indie developers at E3 by giving 
them the freedom to self publish on the PS4. This means we'll be seeing a 
lot of indie love on the Playstation 4. Microsoft focus on big indie titles 
like Minecraft and World of Tanks pales in comparison to the 35 announced 
indie games on the PS4.

2. More powerful hardware

Now this is a controversial one but the general consensus seems to be that 
Sony has the more powerful box. It has a better GPU and faster memory 
compared to the Xbox One although Microsoft could boost the performance 
with cloud computing. We'll just have to wait and see if games will look 
and run better on the PS4 but on paper it seems like Sony definitely has 
the edge here.

1. It's gamer focused

If you like the idea of talking and gesturing to your console, or if you're 
into live sports and TV in a big way, the Xbox One is probably the console 
for you. But if you're like us and couldn't care less about any of that 
stuff, you should probably go with a PS4. It seems like Sony is providing 
the more purist gaming machine this time around with lots of hardcore 
exclusives that are meant to be played with a controller. ﻿

It's the contrast which is making the difference. The PS4 renders the 
details such that the contrast is comparatively low and hence everything 
just blends in and gives it a 'softer' look. Whereas Xbox One has a higher 
contrast setting and we can differentiate minute differences like threads 
in a seat belt, things like that. Both systems can render textures equally 
good, it's the contrast and brightness setting which makes a lot of 
difference. Both these settings can obviously be adjusted, so people 
looking for graphics need not be worried if they think they got the wrong 
console. ﻿

Final verdict is: Go for the PS4 if you love to game a lot on console. Go 
for the Xbox One if you have a healthy balance of gaming and entertainment.

(PLEASE READ!) Dear friendly gamers across all platforms, to get it out of 
the way, I am a ps4 owner. I am satisfied with my purchase, as the time of 
purchase was more wallet friendly. Although, as an original xbox fan, my 
plans were to purchase the xb1 until later speculating that it was an extra 
$100, therefore I had chosen otherwise. Later I found out that the PS4 had 
the better specs (running games at 1080p at a max of 60fps) so i thought to 
myself, "great" I've got a powerhouse of a console! Of course its not to 
say the PS4 is better, because in all honesty, I see features on the XB1 I 
envy. The feeling could be mutual for any XB1 owner. My belief is we are 
defending our purchase rather than our blunt and sometimes irrational 
honesty. These are both great consoles, but if we are talking about specs, 
the ps4 wins. On the  XB1 in many videos, it looks prettier, whether it be 
due to contrast or not I dont really care. On the ps4 side, the realism is 
where this console shows it off. Bottom line, if your satisfied with your 
purchase, don't defend it if you believe it can hold it's own against its 
competitor, just enjoy your gameplay and the raw capabilities of your 
console. To the PC owners: I own a PC, and of course these are monsters of 
gaming due to interchangeable parts and a whole list of good stuff but 
these my friend, are "console wars" for a reason so lets keep the focus on 
consoles. Wheter your choice be the xb1 for its impressing kinect motion 
capabilites and multimedia activities or the ps4 for it's raw power as a 
console primarily for gaming, you've made a great choice that has satisfied

The pictures you are pulling are from online media, like youtube videos. 
They have a limited memory size for images being stored, and I'm fairly 
certain that memory size is constant. What I mean is that when you turn 
your video quality up or down, it's not retrieving a different cache of 
higher or lower resolution images, it just scales the image you see based 
on the data it has. 

Someone please correct me if they know this isn't how it works, I would 
like to know for certain.

If that is how it works, then the reason the PS4 looks "muddier" in your 
comparison video is simply because the PS4 renders natively in 1080p and 
the XBox One renders natively in 720p. The data stored in the video will 
put them both at the same size, and then scale them from there, meaning 
that the video's cache size was closer to the XBox One's rendering 
resolution and caused less conversion error than it did for the PS4. . 
Almost everyone I've heard who's seen it on both consoles talks about how 
crisp it looks on the PS4. 

This video is like those HD TV commercials you always see. It'll say "buy 
our TV cuz it looks sooo real!" and they proceed to show you the TV 
running, seemingly oblivious of the fact that the viewer is incapable of 
telling the difference because they're viewing it through the limitations 
of their current TV. ﻿

There's something NO ONE seems to understand. Why do PS4 games look cooler 
than PS3? Answer. Resolution? Nah. Graphics? Yeah, of course. Lightning? 
YES. THERE'S the answer. The massive improvement in the lightning. Remember 
what a PS3 game looked like in Modern Warfare or Black Ops when watching a 
pebble in the forest or something? Lots of different textures all mixed up, 
shiny as hell and not real looking. The PS4 toned this down because this 
layer of softness is the thing that is making the games look really 
next-gen. Consoles can' reproduce life-like games, so they can't have so 
many different textures to look real looking. Thats why games like COD 
failed in PS3. Stare at a tree. My god. Shitty textures everywhere, colours 
fixed in a position with no translucency. The layer of softness makes the 
world look better cause there aren't DETAILS which you see and say "Wow, 
this looks so unrealistic". The softness mixes with the colours and gives 
you this sense of the colours mixing up and complementing, resulting in a 
better picture, cause just watching pure detail would give away the sense 
of realism, as it can't reproduce them at a perfection. It is a way of 
HIDING the stuff consoles can't do at 2014. PS5 might just look like a 
movie, but that will take years. Just play COD on PS3 and play a 
Multiplayer match on Battlefield 4 (Ghosts has shitty graphics in PS3 and 
PS4 so don't mind buying it).﻿

The reason why the PS4 looks blurry and the Xbox One does not is because 
the PS4 had the extra power to run post process AA. The negative to this 
being that post process AA causes a disgusting amount of blur. It's why PC 
players tend to turn it off and opt for MSAA or no AA in order to preserve 
detail. (Or to obtain lower frame latency) I myself prefer to skip the post 
process AA because of the blur it causes. The extreme amount of jagged 
edges on the Xbox version and the blurry lack of jaggies on the PS4 version 
is proof enough. It's simply a matter of FXAA (Or something similar) making 
the image less jagged at the cost of fine detail.. which you'd most likely 
not notice on your couch anyway. As for the contrast/lighting.. Xbox does 
use DX11 which is an advantage in the effects area of 
things.(Lighting/Shaders) Considering BF4 runs DX11 native on windows and 
Xbox it'd make sense that the modified OpenGL version on PS4 would be less 
refined. Sorry to say but this video feels like misinformation. (Makes the 
Xbox seem flat out better) Let me be clear. The lack of post process AA is 
not a positive thing for the Xbox to be missing, despite the positive 
effect it had on sharpness. You are more likely to notice aliasing than you 
are fine detail loss from typical console viewing distances. I'd also like 
to mention the PS4 suffers less from screen tearing. So while the PS4 has 
more horsepower, the Xbox will benefit greatly from multiplatform titles 
that utilize DX11 since it's often the preferred API on PC. (Where they 
create the games and where they sell PC copies.) This post was not meant to 
be biased 'fanboy' banter and hopefully it was more informative than 
'troll' sounding. I just felt the need to assure folks that there's more to 
it technically than a simple glance at screenshots. (Posted for you 
potential consumers to consider.)﻿

PS4's hardware is significantly more powerful than Xbox One's - check out 
the fullysourced and up to date comparison chart:

http://gamrconnect.vgchartz.com/thread.php?id=136756

The biggest thing you should know is that the PS4 GPU is, at a minimum, 40% 
more powerful than Xbox One's. It's capable of far more raw calculations 
per second, as well as having the added benefit of using the additional 
headroom to take advantage of GPGPU features - where the GPU will take 
considerable load off of the CPU. The PS4 GPU's floating point 
performance is measured at 1.84TFLOPS, while Xbox One's is at 1.3TFLOPS. To 
put that into context, the WiiU's GPU puts out about 350GFLOPS, 
or 0.35TFLOPS. A major advantage to PS4's GPU is that while being of the 
same base architecture as Xbox One's, it has 50% moreshaders; there are 768 
shaders on Xbox One's GPU, and 1152 on PS4's. This is one of the biggest 
differences between the two machines, and something a lot of gamers aren't 
aware of. An attribute such as this heavily dictates the performance of a 
GPU, and it should be noted that when a PC gamer is purchasing a new GPU, 
the higher end cards' within the same architecture will have one of their 
appealing factors be the fact that they've got more shaders; think of it as 
going from dual core to quad core, but tied more to graphics performance. 
The shader advantage PS4 has is one of its most important factors. We can 
directly compare the disparity between the two, notice they're the same 
architecture, and see how more powerful hardware of that very same 
architecture lends itself to improved performance. There is no room for 
debate on this topic either, as it's simply mathematics that lend to how 
many calculations per second the PS4 GPU can put out.

Another important thing is the memory. While both consoles have 8GB of RAM, 
PS4's is GDDR5, and Xbox's is DDR3. This gives PS4 a huge memory bandwidth 
advantage; it's far more capable of moving data around more quickly. PS4's 
memory bandwidth is 176GB/s, while Xbox's is 68.3. Xbox One does have 32MB 
of eSRAM @ ~103GB/s to compensate, but that memory doesn't have the same 
purpose as typical system/video memory. Rather, it's actually 
a framebuffer. There are additional hardware advantages that I will list 
later on, but these are the primary facts you should know.

If you would like further information on PS4's hardware superiority, check 
out this interview with AMD during Gamescom from one of Germany's largest 
tech sites where PS4's use of hUMA gives it an even more substantial RAM 
advantage:

You are actually repeating false propaganda. MASSIVE resolution jump is an 
over sale. In commercial products its 720p to 1080p is one step, making 
720p to 900p half of a step. If we were talking 720p or 1080p to 4k or even 
2k the term MASSIVE could be used. Thats the first problem.

Next is your contrast and fact are wrong. These games are upscaled to 
1080p. You are not comparing a 900p image to a 720p image in this game. You 
are comparing a 720p image upscaled to 1080p to a 900p image upscaled to 
1080p. This leaves room for for more interpretation and from what it seems 
the Xbox One has a better upscaler so in these conditions it can create an 
image with an advantage in sharpness and detail. There is more than one way 
too skin a cat pumping out as many native polygons as you can is not the 
only way to make a great looking game... is it one way and probably the 
most optimal way.... Yes. But is it the ONLY way..... NO.

Another thing since the images are upscaled you are not getting more pixels 
on screen. The gaming media has been mis educating the public to keep favor 
with the Sony Pony crowd. The reality is you arent getting more pixels you 
are just getting more directly controlled pixels. Depending on the image it 
could not even matter. Since the beginning everyone has been trying to 
crown Ps4 as the king system so they have been very flakey with the logic 
and reporting. Right now there is only 1 game that the Ps4 runs at 1080p 
and the X1 runs 720p and that COD. EVery other game the X1 is either the 
same or half a step back in native resolution like BF4... and you would 
have to be blind to deny that you cant see the sharpness in the difference 
between to 2 systems. Alas you would also have to be blind to not notice 
that the Ps4 version keeps smoother lines in heavily contrasted spots.

1:
the gpu is always a scaleable part of the system - 30% more ore less is not

2:
the PS 4 is not really 30% stronger because its render cores work with less 
MHz , so depending on what u wanna do it's whether equally to have more 
weaker cores or less but therefore faster cores OR it's even better to have 
stronger cores because there are still too many things that can't be 
splitter into endless amount of render packages , so too many cores don't 
allways scale performance 1:1 up !
and the ps4 takes most of it's advantage out of the additional 6 render 
cores that lack nearly 60 MHz to it's Xbox one sisters ;)

let's say IT HAS 30% more powerfull gpu, if it's true or not doesn't matter

in,general and how do u guys think that a 30% more powerfull machine could 
handle 70% higher render density with ease ?????
- right, it CAN'T. !!!
That's why bf4 has better overall picture quality on the Xbox and why COD

at 52fps on the ps4 !
